sentences.sentence: The time that had been decided upon for Elizabeth’s northern tour with the Gardiners had almost arrived,
when a letter came from Mrs. Gardiner, announcing that their trip would both begin later and end earlier than originally planned.
Mr. Gardiner had business to attend( 照料 ) to that would delay their trip until two weeks later in July, and he needed to be back in London again within a month.
Since that did not leave enough time for them to go as far as originally planned, and to see as much as had been originally suggested, they were forced to give up on going to the Lake District.
They would instead take a significantly( 相当地 ) shorter tour, and go no farther north than Derbyshire.
The Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the next morning with Elizabeth.
They now traveled toward the little town of Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner had lived before she was married.
After having seen all the main wonders of the country, Elizabeth was informed by her aunt that Mr. Darcy’s home at Pemberley was only five miles away from Lambton.
Mrs. Gardiner had gone there once before, and expressed a desire to see the place again.
Mr. Gardiner agreed to go along, and asked Elizabeth for her opinion.
“My love, why would you not want to see a place of which you have heard so much?” said her aunt,
“a place which is also connected to( 和...有联系 ) so many of your acquaintances( 熟人 ).
Wickham spent his childhood there, you know.”
Elizabeth was distressed( 痛苦的 ).
She felt that she had no reason to be at Pemberley, and wanted to express clearly her reluctance( 不情愿 ) to visit it.
She immediately thought of how dreadful( 可怕的 ) it would be if she happened to run into Mr. Darcy while visiting there.
Therefore, when she went to bed that night, she asked the maid( 女仆 ) whether or not Pemberley was a very fine place,
what the name of its owner was, and somewhat nervously asked also whether the family were there during the summer.

The maid( 女仆 ) responded in the negative( 否定的 ) to the last question, and since Elizabeth now had nothing to fear in such a visit, she began to feel a great deal of curiosity to see the house for herself.
When the subject was again mentioned the next morning, she was at ease enough to answer that she did not mind visiting the place.
Thus it was decided that they were to go to Pemberley.
Elizabeth watched with some concern as they drove along toward Pemberley.
When at last they turned onto the path toward the house, her heart was all of a flutter( 不安 ).
The grounds surrounding( 围绕 ) the house were very large, and contained a great variety( 种类 ) of landscapes( 景观 ).
They entered at one of lowest points of the grounds, and drove for some time through a beautiful forest stretching( 延伸 ) over a wide area.
Elizabeth’s mind was too full for her to be able to make conversation, but she saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view.
The road rose gradually( 慢慢地 ) higher for half a mile, and then they found themselves at the top of a fairly large hill, where the forest ended.
Elizabeth immediately saw Pemberley House for the first time, sitting on the opposite( 对面的 ) side of a valley.
It was a large, attractive stone building, and behind it was a ridge( 山脊 ) of high woody hills.
In front of the house was a fast-running stream that had been enlarged, but without losing any of its natural liveliness and beauty.
Elizabeth was delighted.
She had never seen a place of greater natural beauty, or one so unspoiled( 未遭破坏的 ) by artificial( 人工的 ) taste.
At that moment she felt that she might actually have been happy living in Pemberley after all!
The housekeeper( 管家 ), Mrs. Reynolds, came.
She was a respectable, elderly woman, and she was far more friendly and less formal( 刻板的 ) with them than they had any right to expect.
They followed her into the dining-room—a large, well-designed room, and beautifully decorated( 装潢 ).
Elizabeth, after quickly looking it over, went to a window to enjoy the view.
She looked at the whole scene: the river, the trees scattered( 分布 ) on its banks, and the winding of the valley.
As far as she could see, everything she saw filled her with delight.
“And to think,” thought she, “that I might have been the mistress( 女主人 ) of this place!
Instead of viewing these lands as a stranger, I might have enjoyed them as my own, and welcomed my uncle and aunt to them as visitors.
But no, that would never have happened.
I would never see my uncle and aunt again, because I would not have been allowed to invite them.”
It was fortunate that she remembered this, because it prevented her from feeling something like regret.
She felt a strong urge( 渴望 ) to ask the housekeeper( 管家 ) if her master was really absent, but did not have the courage to do so.
At last however, her uncle asked the question.
Mrs. Reynolds replied that he was away, adding, “But we expect him tomorrow, with a large group of friends( 朋友 ).”
Elizabeth was very relieved that their own journey had not been delayed for even a single day!
Her aunt now called her to look at a picture.
It was of Mr. Wickham, in his younger days.
The housekeeper( 管家 ) told them that it was a picture of the son of Pemberley’s former steward( 管家 ), and that the late Mr. Darcy had paid for him to have a good education.
“But now he has gone into the army, and I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”
“And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the pictures, “is my master.
It was painted about eight years ago.”
“I have heard much about your master’s fine appearance,” said Mrs. Gardiner, looking at the picture.
“He has a handsome face.
But, Lizzy, you can tell us whether it looks like him or not.”
Mrs. Reynolds’s respect seemed to increase at hearing that Elizabeth knew her master.
“Does that young lady know Mr. Darcy?”
Elizabeth turned red, and said: “A little.”
“And do you agree that he is a very handsome gentleman, ma’am?”
“Yes, very handsome.”
“Is your master often at Pemberley throughout( 一直 ) the year?”
“Not as much as I might wish, but I would say that he spends about half of his time here.”
“If your master were to marry, you might see more of him,” said Mrs. Gardiner.
“Yes, madam( 女士 ), but I do not know when that will be.
I do not know who is good enough for him.”
Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner smiled.
Elizabeth could not help saying, “It is very much to his credit, I am sure, that you think so.”
“I say no more than the truth, and everybody that knows him will say so,” replied the housekeeper( 管家 ).
Elizabeth thought this was a remarkably strong statement, and she listened with increasing astonishment( 震惊 ) as the housekeeper( 管家 ) added,
“I have never heard an unkind word from him in my life, and I have known him ever since he was four years old.”

article_info.previous: 最后，Elizabeth把William的种种恶行全都告诉了Jane，得知Mr. Wickham的真实面目以后，姐妹们考虑了种种因素，还是决定不把Mr. Wickham的品行公之于众。Lydia收到了与Foster同行去Brighton的邀请，Elizabeth很开心Mr. Wickham随军团离开的同时又开始担心妹妹Lydia。
article_info.share_words:
Elizabeth was delighted.
She had never seen a place of greater natural beauty, or one so unspoiled by artificial taste.

question.cn: Gardiner一行人的旅程发生了什么变化？
question.en: What changes had happened to  the Gardiners' tour?

analysis: 文中提到：“They would instead take a significantly shorter tour, and go no farther north than Derbyshire.”所以选B。

question.en: Why was Elizabeth reluctant to visit Pemberley?

options.en: Because she was afraid to run into Mr. Wickham.
Because she was afraid to run into Mr. Bingley.
Because she was afraid to run into Mr. Darcy.

analysis: 文中提到：“She immediately thought of how dreadful it would be if she happened to run into Mr. Darcy while visiting there.” 所以选C。

question.cn: Elizabeth对于Pemberley的景色感受是怎样的？
question.en: How did Elizabeth feel about the scenery of Pemberley?

options.cn: 她非常高兴并且非常欣赏这种自然美景。
options.en: She was delighted and admired the natural beauty very much.

analysis: 文中提到：“……but she saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view.”可知正确选项为A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第87天
